importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the current context of the UN's urgent call for global early-warning system improvements amid escalating extreme weather events.

This date references the specific instance in May 2025 when scientists detected an imminent glacier collapse in Switzerland, enabling evacuation of the village of Blatten and illustrating the real-time impact of early warning systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The entire timeframe of 2025 is highlighted as a period of severe weather disasters, including floods and wildfires, reinforcing the urgency of improving global early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of deaths over the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
The WMO reports over 2 million deaths from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the last 50 years.
While 108 countries now use multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functional websites and standardized alerts.
Early warnings must lead to early action; the WMO aims to empower communities, not just warn them.
Major disasters in 2025 include floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US.
Switzerland’s glacier collapse warning in May 2025 allowed evacuation of Blatten, showing the life-saving potential of monitoring and alerts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), under the United Nations, has issued a global call to action to improve early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of the world’s countries lack adequate systems, resulting in thousands of deaths—especially in developing nations. Over the past 50 years, weather-related disasters have killed over 2 million people, with 90% of deaths occurring in vulnerable regions. While progress has been made with 108 countries now using early warnings, half still have only basic capacity. Real-world examples like the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland and floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US highlight the urgency. The WMO and local leaders emphasize that early warnings must lead to early action, and that building monitoring capacity—especially in fragile and conflict-affected areas—is vital to saving lives and protecting infrastructure.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
